metadata.project: Lewis & Clark College Reading Series Archive
metadata.notes: Merged with batch1 and batch2 audit data. 21/108 writers fully audited.

writers.name: Michael Ondaatje
writers.bio: Sri Lankan-born Canadian poet and novelist whose work blends myth, history, and lyrical prose. His novel The English Patient won the Booker Prize and was adapted into an Academy Award-winning film.
notableWorks: In the Skin of a Lion
The Collected Works of Billy the Kid

writers.name: Natalie Diaz
writers.bio: Mojave American poet, language activist, and MacArthur Fellow. Her collection Postcolonial Love Poem won the 2021 Pulitzer Prize for Poetry. She is enrolled in the Gila River Indian Community and works on Mojave language preservation.
notableWorks: When My Brother Was an Aztec

photo.attribution: John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation
photo.notes: High-resolution photos available from MacArthur Foundation; also on ASU faculty page and Poetry Foundation

writers.name: Nikky Finney
writers.bio: South Carolina-born poet whose work explores African American history, civil rights, and Southern heritage. Her collection Head Off & Split won the 2011 National Book Award for Poetry. She is a founding member of the Affrilachian Poets.
notableWorks: Love Child's Hotbed of Occasional Poetry

photo.notes: Photo on National Book Foundation page; also on Poetry Foundation and Academy of American Poets

writers.name: Aamina Ahmad
writers.bio: Pakistani-American novelist and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut novel The Return of Faraz Ali won the L.A. Times Art Seidenbaum Award and was named a Best Book of the Year by The New York Times and NPR.
awards: Writers' Guild of Great Britain First Book Prize

photo.notes: Photo available on official author website and Penguin Random House publisher page

writers.name: Adam Bradley
writers.bio: Literary scholar and Lewis & Clark College alum who pioneered the academic study of hip-hop lyrics as poetry. Professor at UCLA and founding director of the Laboratory for Race & Popular Culture.
notableWorks: Book of Rhymes: The Poetics of Hip Hop

photo.notes: Photo on UCLA faculty page; additional photos by Stephanie Yantz in UCLA College Magazine profile

writers.name: Ada Limón
writers.bio: The 24th U.S. Poet Laureate and the first Latina to hold the position. Her collection The Carrying won the National Book Critics Circle Award, and she was appointed to a historic two-year second term as laureate.

photo.notes: Multiple photos on Wikimedia Commons; also Library of Congress photos by Shawn Miller

writers.name: Alan Shapiro
writers.bio: American poet and former William R. Kenan Jr. Distinguished Professor at UNC Chapel Hill. His collection Night of the Republic was a finalist for both the National Book Award and the Griffin Poetry Prize.

photo.attribution: UNC Dept. of English / Steve Exum
photo.notes: Photos on UNC English department pages; photo by Steve Exum in Wilson Library; Griffin Poetry Prize page also has photo

writers.name: Alexia Arthurs
writers.bio: Jamaican-American fiction writer and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut story collection How to Love a Jamaican won the Paris Review's Plimpton Prize and explores the Jamaican immigrant experience.

photo.notes: Author photo by Rose Marie Cromwell on official website and publisher pages

writers.name: Alexis M. Smith
writers.bio: Pacific Northwest novelist whose debut Glaciers was an Oregon Book Award finalist. Her second novel Marrow Island won the Pacific Northwest Booksellers Association Award and a Lambda Literary Award.

photo.notes: Photo by Annie Beedy on Tin House author page

writers.name: Alix Ohlin
writers.bio: Canadian novelist and short story writer. Her novel Dual Citizens was shortlisted for the Scotiabank Giller Prize, and her collection We Want What We Want won the Lambda Literary Award for Bisexual Literature.
awards: Rogers Writers' Trust Fiction Prize shortlist

photo.notes: Photos by Emily Cooper and Stephanie Noritz; available on official website, UBC Creative Writing faculty page, and Penguin Random House

writers.name: Ama Codjoe
writers.bio: American poet and dancer. Her collection Bluest Nude won the 2023 Lenore Marshall Poetry Prize and a Whiting Award. She was appointed the second Poet-in-Residence at the Guggenheim Museum.

photo.attribution: David Heald / Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation
photo.notes: Photo by David Heald for Guggenheim Museum; also photos on Poetry Foundation and official website

writers.name: Anis Mojgani
writers.bio: Spoken word poet and Oregon's 10th Poet Laureate (2020-2024). He won back-to-back National Poetry Slam titles in 2005-2006, and his book The Feather Room was a National Book Award nominee.
awards: Academy of American Poets Laureate Fellowship

photo.notes: Press photos available for download on official website (The Piano Farm); Oregon Cultural Trust also has photos from laureate tenure

writers.name: Anna Keesey
writers.bio: Oregon-based novelist and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut Little Century, set in 1900 Central Oregon, was praised by The Washington Post as a work about 'who will inherit the earth.'
awards: National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship

photo.notes: Photo on Linfield University faculty page; also available on Macmillan author page and MacDowell artist page

writers.name: Arthur Bradford
writers.bio: American writer and filmmaker whose debut story collection Dogwalker was praised by David Sedaris as the work of 'the most outlandish and energetic writer I can think of.' His stories have appeared in McSweeney's and Esquire.

photo.notes: Photo on MacDowell artist page; also IMDB page and DC/DOX festival page

writers.name: Betsy Amster
writers.bio: Literary agent and former editor at Pantheon and Vintage. She founded Betsy Amster Literary Enterprises in 1992 and has been called 'a dogged prospector of literary talent' by the Los Angeles Times. A frequent panelist at the LA Times Festival of Books and instructor at UCLA Extension's Writers' Program.

photo.notes: Photo available on LA Times Festival of Books speaker page; also on Publishers Marketplace profile

writers.name: Brenda Hillman
writers.bio: Award-winning poet and Chancellor of the Academy of American Poets. Her collection Seasonal Works with Letters on Fire won the 2014 Griffin Poetry Prize. She is the Olivia Filippi Professor of Poetry at Saint Mary's College of California and is married to fellow poet Robert Hass.
notableWorks: Seasonal Works with Letters on Fire
Extra Hidden Life, Among the Days
In a Few Minutes Before Later

photo.notes: Photo by Robert Hass available on Blue Flower Arts speaker page; also on Poetry Foundation, Academy of American Poets

writers.name: Catherine Barnett
writers.bio: Poet and educator whose collection The Game of Boxes won the James Laughlin Award. She is a recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship and a 2022 Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She teaches at NYU and serves as Distinguished Lecturer at Hunter College.
notableWorks: Solutions for the Problem of Bodies in Space
Into Perfect Spheres Such Holes Are Pierced
awards: American Academy of Arts and Letters Award in Literature

photo.notes: Photo by Jacqueline Mia Foster on Academy of American Poets, Poetry Foundation, and official website

writers.name: Catherine Ellis
writers.bio: Writer and oral historian. Co-editor with Sydney Lewis of Say It Plain: A Century of Great African American Speeches, preserving and publishing works from Studs Terkel's interview archive.
notableWorks: Say It Plain: A Century of Great African American Speeches
Say It Loud: Great Speeches on Civil Rights and African American Identity

photo.notes: Limited online presence. Photo may be available through The New Press publisher page. Requires further verification.

writers.name: Charif Shanahan
writers.bio: Poet and translator whose collection Trace Evidence was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, longlisted for the National Book Award, and won the Lambda Literary Award for Gay Poetry. He is an assistant professor at Northwestern University.
notableWorks: Into Each Room We Enter without Knowing
awards: Lambda Literary Award for Gay Poetry
National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship

photo.notes: Photo by Rachel Eliza Griffiths on Northwestern faculty page; also credited to Beowulf Sheehan on some pages

writers.name: Charles Baxter
writers.bio: Novelist and short story writer whose The Feast of Love was a National Book Award finalist. He was the Edelstein-Keller Professor in Creative Writing at the University of Minnesota and has won the Rea Award and PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story.
notableWorks: There's Something I Want You to Do
Burning Down the House: Essays on Fiction
awards: American Academy of Arts and Letters Award

photo.notes: Photo on University of Minnesota English department page; additional photo by Aaron Lavinsky in Minneapolis Sculpture Garden for Star Tribune

writers.name: Christine Deavel
writers.bio: Poet and playwright whose collection Woodnote won the Washington State Book Award and the Dorothy Brunsman Poetry Prize. She co-founded and ran Open Books, Seattle's poetry-only bookstore, with her husband J.W. Marshall from 1995 to 2016.

photo.attribution: Artist Trust / Photo courtesy of the artist
photo.notes: Photo on Artist Trust page; also may have photos from KUOW interview and Seattle Arts & Lectures

writers.name: Claire Vaye Watkins
writers.bio: Author whose debut story collection Battleborn won The Story Prize and Dylan Thomas Prize. Her novel Gold Fame Citrus explores the California drought. A National Book Foundation 5 Under 35 honoree and Guggenheim Fellow, she is a professor at UC Irvine.
notableWorks: I Love You but I've Chosen Darkness
awards: NY Public Library Young Lions Fiction Award

photo.notes: Photo by Lise Watkins on Community of Writers bio page; also on Penguin Random House and Lannan Foundation pages

writers.name: Consuelo Wise
writers.bio: Guatemalan-American poet and Lewis & Clark College alumna (BA '09). Her debut hybrid collection boy is a book-length poem confronting grief over the loss of her two brothers. She is a visiting scholar at Portland State University.

photo.notes: Photo on Lewis & Clark College Visiting Writers Series event page; also on New Orleans Poetry Festival and Portland State faculty pages

writers.name: Corey Van Landingham
writers.bio: Poet and Lewis & Clark College alumna from Ashland, Oregon. Her collection Love Letter to Who Owns the Heavens won the Levis Reading Prize. She is a recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship, NEA Fellowship, and Wallace Stegner Fellowship, and teaches at the University of Illinois.
notableWorks: Love Letter to Who Owns the Heavens
awards: Ohio State University Press/The Journal Charles B. Wheeler Prize

photo.notes: Photo by Anna Longworth on official website; also on Poetry Foundation, NEA, and University of Illinois pages

writers.name: D.A. Powell
writers.bio: American poet whose book Useless Landscape won the National Book Critics Circle Award. His trilogy on the AIDS epidemic (Tea, Lunch, Cocktails) established him as a major voice in contemporary poetry. Professor at University of San Francisco.
notableWorks: Useless Landscape, or A Guide for Boys

photo.notes: Photo by Ben Decastro on Poetry Foundation; also on USF faculty page and Academy of American Poets

writers.name: David Baker
writers.bio: Poet of the American Midwest who served as poetry editor of the Kenyon Review for over 25 years. Emeritus Professor of English at Denison University. His poems explore an individual's sense of engagement with their natural surroundings.

photo.notes: Photo on Denison University faculty page; also on Kenyon Review contributor page and Poetry Foundation

writers.name: Derrick Austin
writers.bio: Poet from Homestead, Florida whose debut Trouble the Water was selected by Mary Szybist for the A. Poulin Jr. Poetry Prize. His collection Tenderness won the Isabella Gardner Poetry Award. Cave Canem fellow and former Stegner Fellow at Stanford.

photo.notes: Author photo by Danny Montemayor on official website; also on Poetry Foundation, Stanford Creative Writing, and BOA Editions

writers.name: Don Waters
writers.bio: Reno-born fiction writer whose debut collection Desert Gothic won the Iowa Short Fiction Award. Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate who teaches at Lewis & Clark College. Lives in Portland with partner Robin Romm.

photo.notes: Photo on official author website; also on University of Iowa Press and Narrative Magazine

writers.name: Elena Passarello
writers.bio: Essayist and actor whose Animals Strike Curious Poses was a New York Times Editor's Choice. First woman to win the Stella Screaming Contest in New Orleans. Directs the MFA program at Oregon State University and lives in Corvallis, Oregon.

photo.notes: Bio and photos page on official website; also on Oregon State University faculty page and Literary Arts

writers.name: Emily Chenoweth
writers.bio: Portland novelist and former Publishers Weekly fiction editor. Her debut Hello Goodbye was an Oregon Book Award finalist. Co-author of the Klawde middle-grade series and collaborator with James Patterson. Lives in Portland with partner Jon Raymond.

photo.notes: Photo on Literary Arts page; also on Penguin Random House author page and PDX Book Fest

writers.name: Emily Wilson
writers.bio: British-American classicist and the first woman to translate Homer's Odyssey into English. Department Chair and Professor of Classical Studies at University of Pennsylvania. Her landmark Odyssey translation was a New York Times 100 Notable Book.
notableWorks: The Greatest Empire: A Life of Seneca

photo.notes: Photo by Imogen Roth; available on UPenn faculty page, MacArthur Foundation, and Literary Arts

writers.name: Endi Bogue Hartigan
writers.bio: Portland poet, Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate, and Truman Capote Fellow. Her collection Pool [5 choruses] won the Omnidawn Open Poetry Book Prize, and One Sun Storm won the Colorado Prize for Poetry. Graduate of Reed College.

photo.notes: Photo by Steven Bloch; available on official website and Academy of American Poets

writers.name: Eric Lundgren
writers.bio: Lewis & Clark College alumnus whose Borgesian debut The Facades was a Barnes & Noble Discover Great New Writers pick and finalist for the William Saroyan International Prize. MFA from Washington University; works at a public library in St. Louis.
awards: Barnes & Noble Discover Great New Writers

photo.notes: Photo by Kevin A. Roberts in St. Louis Magazine; additional photo by Gena Brady on publisher pages

writers.name: Eric Schlosser
writers.bio: Investigative journalist whose Fast Food Nation became a landmark exposé of the American food industry. His Command and Control was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Correspondent for The Atlantic and appeared in Food, Inc. documentaries.

photo.notes: Photo by Jim Scherer; available on Penguin Random House author page and Harry Walker Agency speaker page

writers.name: Erin Ergenbright
writers.bio: Portland writer, Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate (James Michener-Paul Engle Fellow), and co-founder of the Loggernaut Reading Series. Has taught at Lewis & Clark College and Portland Community College, and co-authored The Ex-Boyfriend Cookbook. Also hosts the Portland Spelling Bee.

photo.notes: Photo on Lewis & Clark College event page; also featured on Literary Hub Loggernaut anniversary article

writers.name: Fady Joudah
writers.bio: Palestinian-American poet and physician whose debut The Earth in the Attic won the Yale Series of Younger Poets. His translations of Mahmoud Darwish introduced Palestinian poetry to American readers. Winner of the 2024 Jackson Poetry Prize and 2024 National Book Award finalist.
notableWorks: Footnotes in the Order of Disappearance

photo.notes: Photo by Cybele Knowles on Academy of American Poets; also on Poetry Foundation and Milkweed Editions

writers.name: Geneviève Hudson
writers.bio: Portland fiction writer and essayist whose novel Boys of Alabama was a finalist for the Oregon Book Award and shortlisted for the Stonewall Book Award. Recipient of MacDowell, Fulbright, Caldera Arts, and Vermont Studio Center fellowships. Originally from Alabama.
notableWorks: A Little in Love with Everyone

photo.notes: Photo by Thomas Teal on official author website; also on Liveright/W.W. Norton publisher page

writers.name: Geoffrey G. O'Brien
writers.bio: Professor at UC Berkeley whose meditative poetry explores perception and public space. Educated at Harvard and the University of Iowa, former Holloway Lecturer in Poetry. Also teaches at San Quentin State Prison through the Prison University Project.

photo.notes: Faculty photo on UC Berkeley English Department page; also on Wave Books author page

writers.name: Gillian Conoley
writers.bio: Poet-in-Residence at Sonoma State University and founder-editor of VOLT Magazine. Her collection Tall Stranger was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award. Recipient of the Shelley Memorial Award for her body of work.

photo.notes: Faculty photo on Sonoma State English Department; also photo by Heather Conley on Poets & Writers profile

writers.name: Hamid Ismailov
writers.bio: Uzbek novelist exiled to the UK whose works remain banned in Uzbekistan. Former BBC World Service Writer in Residence for 25 years. His novel The Devils' Dance won the EBRD Literary Prize. Born in Tokmok, Kyrgyzstan in 1954.

photo.notes: Author illustration by Soraya Gilanni Viljoen on Tilted Axis Press; photo by Dani Ismailov on The National News

writers.name: Henry Carlisle
writers.bio: San Francisco-born novelist (1926-2011) descended from Nantucket whalers. With his wife Olga Andreyeva Carlisle, he smuggled and translated Solzhenitsyn's manuscripts. The Jonah Man fictionalizes the Essex disaster. Former PEN American Center president and taught fiction at Squaw Valley Community of Writers for 20 years.
notableWorks: Voyage to the First of December
The Land Where the Sun Dies

photo.notes: Photo by Chris Hardy in SF Chronicle obituary; taught at Squaw Valley for 20 years

writers.name: Hillel Schwartz
writers.bio: Cultural historian (born 1948) and poet whose Never Satisfied traces America's obsession with dieting. Also authored The Culture of the Copy and Making Noise. Recipient of the 2014 Berlin Prize in Cultural History from the American Academy in Berlin. Degrees from Brandeis, Yale, and UC Berkeley.
notableWorks: Never Satisfied: A Cultural History of Diets, Fantasies and Fat
Making Noise: From Babel to the Big Bang, and Beyond

photo.notes: Photo by Annette Hornischer on American Academy in Berlin page

writers.name: Ismet Prcic
writers.bio: Bosnian-American novelist (born 1977 in Tuzla) who fled his war-torn homeland in 1996. His debut Shards won the Sue Kaufman Prize, LA Times Art Seidenbaum Award, and Oregon Book Award. Also a Sundance and Jerusalem Screenwriting Lab fellow. Lives in Portland, Oregon.
awards: Sue Kaufman Prize for First Fiction

photo.notes: Photo on Community of Writers bio page; also on BOMB Magazine interview and Simon & Schuster author page

writers.name: J. Hillis Miller
writers.bio: Major American literary critic (1928-2021) and last surviving member of the Yale School of Deconstruction alongside Paul de Man, Jacques Derrida, and Geoffrey Hartman. Former MLA president (1986) and wrote over 50 books analyzing literature through deconstructionist principles. Taught at Johns Hopkins, Yale, and UC Irvine.

photo.notes: Photo by Jeremy Maryott on UCI School of Humanities memorial page; J. Hillis Miller papers including photos at UCI

writers.name: Jacques J. Rancourt
writers.bio: Maine-raised, San Francisco-based poet and former Stegner Fellow. His debut Novena won the Lena-Miles Wever Todd Prize and explores coming-of-age and coming out. Brocken Spectre was named one of Oprah Daily's best LGBTQ books of 2021. Currently works as a middle school principal.

photo.notes: Photo by Danny Chung on Michigan Quarterly Review; courtesy photo on Poetry Foundation

writers.name: James Anderson
writers.bio: Reed College graduate whose debut The Never-Open Desert Diner was praised by The Washington Post as 'outstanding in every regard.' Former publisher and Editor-in-Chief of Breitenbush Books (1975-1991). Also co-produced Tara's Daughters, narrated by Susan Sarandon, which won Best Documentary at the New York Film Festival. Divides time between Colorado and Oregon.

photo.notes: Photo on official author website; also on Penguin Random House and Goodreads author pages

writers.name: Jane Wong
writers.bio: Chinese American poet whose How to Not Be Afraid of Everything was longlisted for the PEN/Voelcker Award. Her memoir Meet Me Tonight in Atlantic City won the 2024 PNBA Award. Associate Professor of Creative Writing at Western Washington University.
notableWorks: Meet Me Tonight in Atlantic City
How to Not Be Afraid of Everything

photo.notes: Author headshot by Gritchelle Fallesgon on official website; header photo by Helene Christensen

writers.name: Jennifer Grotz
writers.bio: Director of the Bread Loaf Writers' Conferences (first woman to hold the position) and Guggenheim Fellow. Her translations of Jerzy Ficowski won the PEN Award for Best Book of Poetry in Translation. Teaches poetry and translation at the University of Rochester.

photo.notes: Photo on Bread Loaf director page; also on University of Rochester faculty page (photo by J. Adam Fenster)

writers.name: James Galvin
writers.bio: Iowa Writers' Workshop faculty member whose Resurrection Update was a finalist for the Los Angeles Times Book Award. His prose meditation The Meadow chronicles life on the Wyoming-Colorado border. Professor Emeritus at Iowa, he divides time between Iowa City and his ranch in Laramie, Wyoming.
notableWorks: Everything We Always Knew Was True

photo.notes: Photo on Iowa Writers' Workshop faculty page; also on Poetry Foundation and Academy of American Poets

writers.name: Joe Wilkins
writers.bio: Montana-raised writer and English Department Chair at Linfield University in Oregon. His poetry collection When We Were Birds won the Oregon Book Award; his novel The Entire Sky won the Montana Book Award. Oregon Literary Arts fellowship recipient.
notableWorks: Fall Back Down When I Die

photo.notes: Photo on Linfield University faculty page; also on Academy of American Poets

writers.name: John Beer
writers.bio: Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate whose The Waste Land and Other Poems won the Norma Farber First Book Award. Formerly Robert Lax's literary assistant on the Greek island of Patmos. Teaches creative writing at Portland State University and lives in Portland, Oregon.
notableWorks: The Waste Land and Other Poems

photo.notes: Photo on Wave Books author page; also on Canarium Books and Poetry Foundation

writers.name: John Casteen
writers.bio: Virginia poet (John T. Casteen IV) and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Associate Professor in UVA's Writing and Rhetoric Program. Former custom furniture builder for ten years whose poems explore physical work and Appalachian landscape.

photo.notes: Photo on UVA English department faculty page; also on personal website johncasteen.net

writers.name: John Farrell
writers.bio: Waldo W. Neikirk Professor of Literature at Claremont McKenna College and NEH Fellowship recipient. His book The Varieties of Authorial Intention has been called 'potentially the most important statement of literary theory to have emerged in this century.'
notableWorks: The Utopian Dilemma in the Western Political Imagination

photo.notes: Photo on CMC faculty profile page

writers.name: John Freeman Gill
writers.bio: Yale summa cum laude (Phi Beta Kappa) graduate and longtime New York Times contributor who writes the Streetscapes column. His debut The Gargoyle Hunters was a Barnes & Noble Discover Great New Writers Selection, praised by Annie Proulx as 'extraordinary.' Architecture and real estate editor at Avenue magazine.

photo.notes: Photo on official author website; also on Penguin Random House and NYS Writers Institute page

writers.name: John Marshall
writers.bio: Pacific Northwest poet and co-founder of Open Books: A Poem Emporium in Seattle (opened 1995), one of only two poetry-only bookstores in the U.S. at the time. Married to fellow poet Christine Deavel. Retired in 2016 after 29 years in the book business.

photo.notes: Photos available on HistoryLink.org article about Open Books; also referenced in Graceguts.com interview with photos from January 2008

writers.name: Jon Raymond
writers.bio: Portland novelist and screenwriter who co-wrote HBO's Mildred Pierce (Emmy-nominated) and collaborates with filmmaker Kelly Reichardt on Old Joy, Wendy and Lucy, and First Cow. His collection Livability won the Oregon Book Award. Former editor at Plazm and Tin House magazines.

photo.notes: Photo by K.B. Dixon on Oregon ArtsWatch and Portland Monthly; also on Literary Arts bio page

writers.name: Joy Katz
writers.bio: Pittsburgh poet and former Stegner Fellow who transitioned from industrial design to poetry. Her collection All You Do Is Perceive was a National Poetry Series finalist. Co-edited Dark Horses: Poets on Overlooked Poems.

writers.name: Julia Elliott
writers.bio: South Carolina fiction writer whose story collection The Wilds was a New York Times Editors' Choice. Her novel The New and Improved Romie Futch blends Southern Gothic with dystopian satire.
notableWorks: The New and Improved Romie Futch

writers.name: Julian May
writers.bio: Pioneering science fiction author who chaired the first worldcon led by a woman (1952). Her Saga of Pliocene Exile series blends time travel with Celtic mythology. Lived in Oregon from the 1970s until her death.

photo.notes: Deceased (1931-2017). Historic Worldcon '52 photo also available on Wikimedia Commons.

writers.name: Karla Kelsey
writers.bio: Experimental poet whose A Conjoined Book weaves lyric with philosophy. Editor of Lost Writings: Two Novels by Mina Loy for Yale University Press. Her first book won the Sawtooth Poetry Prize.

writers.name: Katherine Dunn
writers.bio: Portland novelist whose cult classic Geek Love was a National Book Award finalist and has been named one of the Great American Novels by The Atlantic. She taught creative writing at Lewis & Clark College and wrote extensively about boxing.

photo.attribution: Katherine Dunn Archives at Lewis & Clark College
photo.notes: Deceased (1945-2016). Papers archived at Lewis & Clark College.

writers.name: Katrina Porteous
writers.bio: Scottish poet and historian based on the Northumberland coast. Her collection Rhizodont won the 2025 Laurel Prize and was shortlisted for the T.S. Eliot Prize. She writes in both English and Northumbrian dialect.

photo.notes: Also: Bloodaxe Books (photo by Tony Griffiths)

writers.name: Kaui Hart Hemmings
writers.bio: Hawaii-born novelist whose debut The Descendants was adapted into an Oscar-winning film starring George Clooney. A former Stegner Fellow, she descends from both Hawaiian royalty and American missionaries.

writers.name: Kevin Prufer
writers.bio: Named 2026-2027 Texas Poet Laureate. His collection Churches was named one of ten best poetry books of the year by The New York Times, and How He Loved Them was longlisted for the Pulitzer Prize.

photo.attribution: Wyatt McSpadden / Academy of American Poets

writers.name: Kim Stafford
writers.bio: Oregon's 9th Poet Laureate (2018-2020) and son of Poet Laureate William Stafford. Founding director of Lewis & Clark College's Northwest Writing Institute, where he has taught since 1979.

writers.name: Laurel Nakanishi
writers.bio: Hawaii-born poet and educator. Her collection Ashore was published by Tupelo Press. She directs Hawaii Open Arts and has received grants from the Fulbright Foundation and NEA.

photo.attribution: Courtesy of Laurel Nakanishi / Academy of American Poets

writers.name: Lawson Fusao Inada
writers.bio: Oregon's 5th Poet Laureate (2006-2010) and Japanese American poet interned during WWII. Co-edited the landmark anthology Aiiieeeee!, which helped establish Asian American literature as a field.

photo.attribution: Poetry Foundation / Lehigh University Digital Archive

writers.name: Layli Long Soldier
writers.bio: Oglala Lakota poet whose debut Whereas won the National Book Critics Circle Award and was a National Book Award finalist. The collection responds to the U.S. government's 2009 apology to Native Americans.

writers.name: Lee Montgomery
writers.bio: Founding editorial director of Tin House Books and executive editor of Tin House magazine. Her memoir The Things Between Us won the Oregon Book Award, and her story collection Whose World Is This? won the Iowa Short Fiction Award.
awards: John Simmons Iowa Short Fiction Award

photo.attribution: Kristina Wright / University of Iowa Press

writers.name: Linda Bierds
writers.bio: MacArthur Fellow (1998) known for elegant historiographic poetry. Taught at University of Washington for over 30 years and her collection Roget's Illusion was longlisted for the National Book Award.

writers.name: Lisa Wells
writers.bio: Portland poet and essayist whose collection The Fix won the Iowa Poetry Prize. Her nonfiction book Believers was a finalist for the PEN E.O. Wilson Literary Science Writing Award.
notableWorks: Believers: Making a Life at the End of the World

writers.name: Lois Leveen
writers.bio: Portland historical novelist. Her debut The Secrets of Mary Bowser was named one of The Oregonian's Top Ten Northwest Books, and Juliet's Nurse became an international bestseller. She has taught at Reed College.

writers.name: Major Jackson
writers.bio: Poetry Editor of The Harvard Review and 2023 inductee to the Academy of Arts & Sciences. His debut Leaving Saturn won the Cave Canem Poetry Prize, and he received an Academy of American Poets fellowship.

writers.name: Marian Pierce
writers.bio: Portland fiction writer and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate who received the James Michener Fellowship. Her collection Finding Land: Stories of Japan draws on her experience working for Japan's National Public Radio.

writers.name: Marianne Boruch
writers.bio: Founded Purdue's MFA program and taught there for 31 years. Her collection The Book of Hours won the $100,000 Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award, one of the largest poetry prizes in the U.S.

writers.name: Marilyn Chin
writers.bio: Pioneering Asian American feminist poet who grew up in Portland after emigrating from Hong Kong. Chancellor of the Academy of American Poets and winner of the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize.
notableWorks: A Portrait of the Self as Nation

writers.name: Marjorie Garber
writers.bio: Harvard Shakespeare scholar and cultural critic. Her book Shakespeare After All was named one of Newsweek's ten best nonfiction books of the year, and Vested Interests: Cross-Dressing and Cultural Anxiety became a landmark in gender studies.

writers.name: Mark Edmundson
writers.bio: University of Virginia professor whose Harper's essay 'On the Uses of the Liberal Arts' became one of the most photocopied essays on American campuses. His book Why Read? argues passionately for literature's power to transform lives.

writers.name: Mark Sarvas
writers.bio: Los Angeles novelist whose Memento Park won the American Book Award and the American Jewish Library Association Fiction Award. Creator of the influential literary blog The Elegant Variation.
awards: American Jewish Library Association Fiction Award

writers.name: Marlena Williams
writers.bio: Lewis & Clark College alumna (BA '14) and Portland writer. Her essay collection Night Mother: A Personal and Cultural History of the Exorcist is a 2025 Oregon Book Award finalist.
notableWorks: Night Mother: A Personal and Cultural History of the Exorcist

writers.name: Martin Harries
writers.bio: UC Irvine professor specializing in twentieth-century theater and modernism. His book Theater After Film examines how postwar theater remade itself in response to cinema and mass culture.

writers.name: Marvin Bell
writers.bio: Iowa's first Poet Laureate and creator of the Dead Man poems. Taught at the Iowa Writers' Workshop for 40 years, mentoring Pulitzer winners Rita Dove, Jorie Graham, and Joy Harjo.
notableWorks: Incarnate: The Collected Dead Man Poems
The Book of the Dead Man

photo.attribution: James Morgan / Academy of American Poets

writers.name: Mary Bisbee-Beek
writers.bio: Portland-based book publicist and marketing consultant with over 35 years in publishing. Owner of READ! A Unique Perspective and Publishing Sherpa. Previously owned Beeksbee Books and worked at University of Michigan Press.

writers.name: Matt Wagner
writers.bio: Literary agent at Fresh Books Literary Agency specializing in nonfiction. Previously sold over a thousand books at Waterside Productions. UC Santa Cruz graduate in Creative Writing.

writers.name: Matthew Korfhage
writers.bio: Portland native and award-winning food critic who wrote for Willamette Week for a decade. Named best food critic in North America (2017) by the Association of Alternative Newsmedia. Holds an MFA in fiction. Now writes for WIRED.
awards: Best Food Critic in North America (2017)

writers.name: Michael McGriff
writers.bio: Oregon poet raised in Coos Bay whose Eternal Sentences won the 2021 Miller Williams Poetry Prize. Founding editor of Tavern Books and recipient of NEA and Lannan fellowships. Currently teaches creative writing at the University of Idaho.
notableWorks: Our Secret Life in the Movies

writers.name: Michael Rankin-Heald
writers.bio: Portland essayist and owner of Perfect Day Publishing, an independent press that has published works by Martha Grover, Nick Jaina, Lisa Wells, and others. Author of Goodbye to the Nervous Apprehension. Also writes for Runner's World.

writers.name: Michele Glazer
writers.bio: Portland poet who teaches in the MFA and BFA programs at Portland State University. Her collection fretwork (2021) followed three previous Iowa University Press collections. Won the Iowa Poetry Prize and AWP Prize. Work has appeared in The New Yorker and Ploughshares.
notableWorks: On Tact, & the Made Up World
It Is Hard to Look at What We Came to Think We'd Come to See

writers.name: Mohamed Asem
writers.bio: Kuwaiti-American memoirist born in the U.S. and raised in Paris. His memoir Stranger in the Pen, published by Portland's Perfect Day Publishing, chronicles his detention at Gatwick Airport and explores identity across cultures. Holds an MFA in Creative Writing from Kingston University, London.

writers.name: Molly Antopol
writers.bio: Stanford professor and former Stegner Fellow whose debut collection The UnAmericans was a National Book Award nominee and won the New York Public Library Young Lions Fiction Award. Also received the French-American Prize, Ribalow Prize, and California Book Award Silver Medal.
awards: New York Public Library Young Lions Fiction Award

writers.name: Paul K. Saint-Amour
writers.bio: Annenberg Professor in the Humanities and Chair of English at University of Pennsylvania. His book The Copywrights won the MLA Prize for a First Book, and Tense Future won the Matei Calinescu Prize. 2022 Guggenheim Fellow.
notableWorks: Tense Future: Modernism, Total War, Encyclopedic Form
The Copywrights: Intellectual Property and the Literary Imagination
awards: MLA Prize for a First Book

writers.name: Paul Merchant
writers.bio: Welsh-born poet and translator who was Director of the William Stafford Archives at Lewis & Clark College. His Some Business of Affinity was an Oregon Book Award finalist. Co-edited two books of William Stafford's meditations with Vincent Wixon.

photo.notes: Limited online presence - may need to contact Lewis & Clark College archives for photo

writers.name: Pauls Toutonghi
writers.bio: Professor of English at Lewis & Clark College. His memoir Dog Gone was adapted into a 2023 Netflix film. His novels include Red Weather and Evel Knievel Days. Married to novelist Peyton Marshall.

writers.name: Peter Ames Carlin
writers.bio: Lewis & Clark College graduate (1985) and Portland-based biographer. His New York Times bestseller Bruce was the first Springsteen biography written with the artist's cooperation. Also authored biographies of Paul Simon, Brian Wilson, and R.E.M.
notableWorks: Homeward Bound: The Life of Paul Simon

writers.name: Peyton Marshall
writers.bio: Reed College and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate whose debut novel Goodhouse was a Dashiell Hammett Prize finalist. She received an NEA Prose Writing Fellowship (2022-23) and lives in Portland with her husband, novelist Pauls Toutonghi.

writers.name: Rebecca Clarren
writers.bio: Portland journalist and 2021 Whiting Nonfiction Grant winner. Her book The Cost of Free Land won the 2025 Oregon Book Award (Frances Fuller Victor Award). Has written investigative stories about the American West for over twenty years.
notableWorks: The Cost of Free Land: Jews, Lakota and an American Inheritance

writers.name: Rick Barot
writers.bio: Filipino American poet born in the Philippines, raised in the San Francisco Bay Area. Poetry editor of New England Review and director of Pacific Lutheran University's Rainier Writing Workshop MFA program.

writers.name: Rob LaZebnik
writers.bio: Harvard Lampoon alumnus and longtime writer/co-executive producer on The Simpsons. Has won five Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Animated Program. His episode 'The Burns Cage' marked Smithers' coming out.

writers.name: Ryan White
writers.bio: Portland music critic and journalist who spent nearly 16 years at The Oregonian. Twice named one of the top feature writers in the country by the Society for Features Journalism. Author of books on Jimmy Buffett and Bruce Springsteen.
notableWorks: Jimmy Buffett: A Good Life All the Way

writers.name: Samiya Bashir
writers.bio: First Black woman to receive the Joseph Brodsky Rome Prize in Literature. Her collection Field Theories won the Oregon Book Award. Former Reed College professor; currently June Jordan Visiting Scholar at Columbia.

writers.name: Tess Gallagher
writers.bio: Washington poet, essayist, and playwright born in Port Angeles. Widow of Raymond Carver and literary executor of his estate. Only American to receive the Fondazione Roma lifetime achievement award for poetry (2023).

writers.name: Vern Rutsala
writers.bio: Taught at Lewis & Clark College for over 40 years and helped start its creative writing program with William Stafford. His collection The Moment's Equation was a National Book Award finalist. Won the 2014 C.E.S. Wood Distinguished Writer Award.

writers.name: Vince Wixon
writers.bio: Ashland poet who co-produced documentary films on William Stafford and Lawson Inada. Co-edited two books on William Stafford for University of Michigan Press with Paul Merchant. Helped establish the William Stafford Archives.

writers.name: Vu Tran
writers.bio: Vietnamese American novelist who directs undergraduate creative writing at University of Chicago. His debut novel Dragonfish explores Vietnamese refugees in Las Vegas. Winner of a Whiting Award.

writers.name: Will Aimé
writers.bio: Portland-based poet.

photo.notes: Instagram CDN URL - may need manual download as CDN URLs can expire

writers.name: Bill Clegg
writers.bio: Literary agent and author. His debut novel Did You Ever Have a Family was longlisted for the Man Booker Prize. Founder of The Clegg Agency representing major literary fiction authors.
notableWorks: Did You Ever Have a Family
Portrait of an Addict as a Young Man

writers.name: William Deresiewicz
writers.bio: Former Yale English professor and National Book Critics Circle Award winner for reviewing. His bestseller Excellent Sheep critiques elite education; The Death of the Artist examines creative work in the digital age.

writers.name: Youssef Rakha
writers.bio: Egyptian novelist and essayist who writes in both Arabic and English. His first novel The Book of the Sultan's Seal won the Banipal Prize. Selected for Hay Festival Beirut39 as one of the best Arab writers under 40.
notableWorks: The Book of the Sultan's Seal

schema.description: Data structure for each writer entry

fields.name: Full name as it should appear on site
fields.years: Array of years they appeared at L&C
fields.genre: poetry | fiction | nonfiction | criticism (can combine with /)
fields.bio: 1-2 sentences, focusing on significance and connection to literary world
fields.awards: Array of major awards (optional, for notable writers)
fields.wikipediaUrl: Link to Wikipedia page if exists, null if not
fields.officialWebsite: Link to author's website if exists, null if not

photo.url: Direct link to image if known
photo.license: CC BY, CC BY-SA, press use, unknown, etc.

fields.confidence: high | medium | low - confidence in data accuracy
